reviewText: Wagner is perfection and Olympia is fantastic. See it!

Adult children encounter difficult decisions when it's apparent their parent(s) are unable to care for themselves in a healthy way. This movie gives great insight and symptoms to watch out for and how to handle/how not to handle circumstances. It's a compassionate, well acted, true to life topic that we need to address more in this American society where dark entertainment has become more the norm.
Both actresses were fantastic, as always.

This movie was a good one.  However, it was a little depressing to me..or rather sad.  It was shipped to me in good condition, in a timely manner and I would recommend this seller again.  This is the second time I have reviewed this item.

I am a huge fan of Lindsay Wagner, and I think Olympia Dukakis is a fantastic actress. They both did a great job in FIRE IN THE DARK--especially Ms. Dukakis. If I didn't know better, I would have thought the actress had gone to the Great Theatre in the Sky the minute the director yelled, "Cut! That's a wrap."  The only reason I didn't give this movie 4 stars is because it feels dated. Compared to the movies of today, it is paced a little slowly. Even so, I sympathized with both characters. I felt their every frustration and their every fear. I even shed a few tears. If you are a fan of either of these actresses, or if you know someone going through the trials and tribulations of growing old and frail, it is worth adding to your collection.

This  movie hit home for me. I was a caregiver for my mom, and it was a strain on my marriage; eventually  we placed her in an adult family home. All family members with elderly parents should watch this movie. Very good!!
I just didn't care for this movie.  It was okay, but the characters didn't seem to have much personality.  Definitely doesn't compare to a Hallmark movie for sure.
wonderful movie about the stresses of aging on the caregivers as well as those who are aging and losing their independence.
Excellent movie with a great cast. I enjoyed watching this movie though it made me sad , brought back so many thoughts of my Mother in her last days. Still a MUST SEE !!
Real life problems handled in a very realistic way.
Great movie, about problems we all face sooner or later

Kind of sad but so real.  I enjoyed it.
i like dukakis, i could really relate to the part where people don't realize how bad their parents are getting.

Olympia Dukakis gives an excellent portrayal of physical and emotional problems faced by the elderly, especially those living alone. Younger audiences can learn a lot from this movie about their elderly loved ones.
Plays with your emotions. Realistic characters even if you dislike some of them.

Poignant story!
It was a good movie.  I could relate to a lot of it since my mother when through many of the same feelings.  It is very educational on all levels.
It was entertaining, acting was fantastic.  This is a subject that we will all be asked to deal with someday as our parents age.
Great movie
I liked the movie, it was dated though, but enjoyable.

For Seniors it makes you stop and think. It is entertaining and depressing at the same time. When are we going to be prepared for Senior
living? Most of us are in denial .........this includes the adult children.

I had to watch this in two sittings. It got tedious and I wasn't sure I would finish it. I did and it had a good ending. It covered a lot of the emotions and challenges both the aging parent and her children go through, based on my own experience. For that I would give it a 4+ rating.
too in touch with reality!!
Great movie!

Wonderful, sensitive movie, which portrays Olyvia Dukasis as a woman who is getting older.  The husband has passed away, the children are married - one ( Lynsay Wagner) married to a philosophy professor trying to work his way up the collegiate "ladder" and the other ( single at age 45 ) a struggling high school math teacher.  However, when Olivia falls and suffers a hip injury she and her children realize that "age is caching up"  This is what the movie is about- the children and the woman "coming to grips" with the fact that she can no longer live in her home alone.  The sensitive,and mature way in which the entire family come to a conclusion as to what the next "steps" should be is what the movie is about.  Well acted, engrossing.
very insightful of the last years of our lives...
Excellent
helped you see the plight of people as they get older and trying to fit in with their own families when they sometimes have to live with them.
Very realistic

This was kind of a tough one to watch.  I don't like watching people suffer or feel out of control, esp the elderly. BUT it is good to watch to better understand the possibilities of our future as we are all getting older.  The acting was amazing as well.  I've always loved Olympia Dukakis and Lindsey Wagner.
Excellent movie

Excellent video of the struggle for independence and the right to take care of one's self as long as possible. Unfortunately, like the video, those in the struggle don't always know when we are in danger and loose sight of when it is time to ask for help. Hopefully, we have loving family or friends to help with a realistic look considering both the elder parent and child.

Smart movie. Everybody wants to take parents in automatically.  Nobody ever realizes how much or how long it will affect the normal and private side of you and the entire family life.  To hear the husband speak so honest about that was an eye opener.

I, too , have managed to stay in my own home so far and hope and pray I will do so for whatever years I have left.  My children help me greatly, but I still drive, even at night, take classes, do everything for myself except cook and take out the trash!  I guess I liked it most because Olympia and Jean both played characters that were determined to keep going forward as much as possible.

Extreme loss of independence that can accompany advanced aging is a tricky subject to take on in film, without overwhelming one's audience. An ensemble of gifted artists, including Olympia Dukakis, Jean Stapleton, Lindsay Wagner, and Edward Hermann perform in this pretty sobering, engaging, and important film, which zeroes in on an aging woman's and her peers' struggle to master shifting physical and mental statuses; as it highlights its effects on family. That search for both emotional and physical safe space is extremely powerful.  Emily (Dukakis), in the lead, is that spry, crusty, self-reliant 75-year-old, who suddenly finds herself utterly helpless. Jean Stapleton, as Henny, adds a bit of comic relief as she delivers some of the best and funniest lines that define her just-keep-on-trucking philosohy of life.  Janet (Lindsay Wagner) is Emily's committed, decision-making daughter, who is called upon for some really tough ones. This is the nitty-gritty of this stage of life, well told by David J. Hill and solidly directed by David Hugh Jones. A very valuable piece, particularly for families dealing with these life events. Recommend.
Reaching old age and the adjustments needed by all family members

Inasmuch as I'm a 73 year old woman, I was able to directly relate to many of the episodic mishaps of the aging mother.  It was interesting to see the differences in the treatment of the mother by both the daughter and son.  I guess that maternal instinct will kick in when it comes to facing the challenges of caring for an elderly parent.  I highly recommend it for watching by both concerned parties as it is definitely a dilemma that more and more families are facing.
Reminded so much of my mom and her situation.
Loved it

This film is food for thought for everyone who has an aging parent. I am one of those aging parents who lives alone. I have known for a long time I need to make contingency plans. I do not want to be found by someone. After viewing this film I have made arrangements that my children will email me at least every third day. If they do not hear from me they will call neighbors. Now, everyone feels more comfortable.

OLympia Dukakis plays an 80 something recently widowed woman. Her daughter lives two hours away, her son lives nearer but rarely visits. It is not until she talks and breaks her hip that her children must move out of their lives and think of her. Lyndsay Wagner plays the daughter who loves her mother, but caring for her will change everyone's lives. Facing the hardships of elder care, the finances and all that entails is part of this film. This is not entertainment as much as informational. As I said, a must see for anyone with older parents.

Still, the topic of an aging parent really doesn't change the fact that families are becoming a Sandwich Generation where they still are raising kids but also have to start caring for aging parents.

Fire in the Dark is a pretty good reminder about the need for us all to accept our aging process. All humans grow old and die eventually (if they are LUCKY). It is fact of life. I think this movie gives a good wake up call about what things all boil down to, eventually. Living life can be difficult and challenging but if we try, it will turn out okay. Our modern culture expects us to be young and strong forever but living shows the reality of the situation. I enjoyed Lindsay Wagner especially but the whole cast was pretty good.

Deeply touching reality of growing old.  Shows the struggles and challenges of body and mind that aging brings.  Letting go of independence and allowing those who love you, to help care for you.  Hit home for me, as my husband and I are in the sandwich generation, with the growing needs of 80 something parents,  while still having a teenager at home.  There are great lessons for each generation.  The most common frustration that was shown in the movie, and we are facing as a family, is the battle of wills to remain independent.  This battle by the elderly person(s) tears at the fabric of family relationships, putting extra stresses and burdens on everyone around.

This movie was hard to watch because it rang so true. I've been the daughter with elderly parents who needed more help than I alone could provide, and as part of the "sandwich generation" our society makes it difficult for everyone involved. I could identify with almost all the characters, or knew someone like them, and it made me relive some painful moments and decisions. This was very raw and very true to life.

Very well done in a soft way. It even pointed out the adult siblings who take grandma's things, ask for money yet barely visit and when they do it's to take valuable things out of the house because they feel entitled even if they are the favored child...and offer nothing but excuses when asked to help in little ways, the mother they are stealing from. Family dynamics close to death are horrible.  The acting was right on and the small look into what was happening with grandma's friends too was interesting. A home these days is probably better than staying in the family home with all the low paid CNA help, and high turn over can make it a nightmare. Your house is ransacked by a stranger, stealing, assaults, a whole litany of things that your vulnerability with folks saying it was just in your head is not a good choice...better a home that is legally accountable for a certain amount of care. And no one really wants to be a burden on their family...so it was a really good film to talk honestly about these issues before it's really needed .  SPOILERS: .She was broken into and neither son was concerned, no one called the police. And the robber, that I'm not so sure wasn't the gimme son, the believed was a name in the paper the gimmie son hired and didn't check out. He even told her he couldn't cut her grass and quit. One thing that really hit home was when grown son says he will come for dinner, not even thinking she might need help and that it is a big deal for her and they either barely show up in time to ask for money again and leave quickly. Or cancel at the last minute as if it was no big deal to her, who has been planning, saving money to buy groceries for a meal that won't be eaten. All I can say is what goes around comes around!
Great movie!

They got her age wrong. It should be 85 instead of 75. She looked and acted more like 85 instead of 75. I'm 89 and I'm around a lot of people around my age/ I know a woman who is 94 and she still takes care of her own house. Like I've always said; the older you are the more you need to walk and exercise.
I REALLY  ENJOYED  THE  MOVIE  ESPECIALLY  ACTOR  LINDSAY WAGNER. JEAN. STAPLETON  OLIVIA. DUKACKIS  IT  WAS  A  PLEASURE  TO  SEE  THESE. ACTRACESSES....

Very good movie. It was emotional, funny and true to life.

I am a 65-year-old woman and wish I had not watched this movie, but for some reason just could not turn it off. The tragedy here is that this was a very "nice" family with assets; however, they ALL behaved badly. The son whined because he was a school teacher and didn't have as many resources as his sister who was a college professor married to a college professor (his sister did encourage him to go back to school so he could teach at college too). This 45-year-old brother lived near his Mom and "used" her to get his laundry done and as a bank when he needed money which was not the result of him being a school teacher (I know a lot of school teachers who don't treat their Mothers like that!). The 40-ish-year-old daughter lived two hours away in her "perfect" world and did step up to help her Mom, but not until her Mom's house was broken into by the jerk the son found in the newspaper to cut her grass. Her husband and son "made nice" about it at first, but it didn't take long for the Mom moving into "their perfect and blissfully successful world" caused problems. Along the way the Mom lost a dear friend and another succumbed to dementia (her daughter left her with a friend who was turning her over to the state). And there was also focus on the psychology of the son being the Mother's favorite as well as other common family-centered issues that were painful to watch. Needless to say this was an extremely disturbing and sad movie. It ended with the Mom going to live in an estate-like VERY nice nursing facility so everyone was happy. Right! Okay, I get it that getting old is a problem for the rich and the poor and and the smart and the not as educated family who "have to take care of the old family member."  Yes, it was a "painful to watch" movie for an "old" person like me who is only going to get older. And by the way, socially/economically, I fall somewhere between this rich family who had resources to deal with the Mom and her friend who was about to be turned over to the state for care. The moral was if you have money, you get to (EVENTUALLY) go live in a NICE place to be cared for, and if you don't have money you get to go to a state supported place to live out your life -- either way, your family doesn't' want to deal with you once you get old and can't make holiday meals for them anymore. Getting old as depicted in American cinema was not entertaining.
great movie got it today ty so much

I have to say that I enjoyed this movie and Lindsay's performance was superb, much more believable acting than many of her other works which to me seemed forced. Here, she is very real in her emotions. Olympia, as always is a wonderful actress. The writing isn't up to the task of these two fine actresses. But I'll give it a pass because their performances and the message is much more important.
it came in great condition

Olympia Dukakis and Lyndsay Wagner play a mother and daughter who are forced to deal with the hardships of life in terms of elder care.  Olympia, a recent widow, must learn to release some of her freedom and the life she led to allow Lyndsay to help her through the rest of her years.

This is not a doom and gloom movie or one where force is used.  Through understanding and compassion, the relationship between mother and daughter deepens. The ending is bitter sweet as Olympia learns to say goodbye to her past and move on to her future with a positive attitude.  (I was teary eyed.)

Both Olympia and Lyndsay portray their characters excellently and believably.  This movie can be watched by teens as well as adults.
Great movie. Very real.
This was a gift & the person was very happy with it. (:

This story might of been written years ago, but it sure covers what we all have to face at one time or another, which is dealing with an elder in the family. I take care of my mother-in-law who is in her early eighties and she used to drive me up the wall. I used to think to myself, "Why does it have to be so difficult? Why is she making things so complicated?  How can we make it work?" After watching this movie, it helped me relate to her more and helped me understand where she was coming from. I've learned to become more patient with her, work things out and love her for who she is. I felt that this movie portrayed a lot of my life story and it helped me understand her more and connect with her by seeing things through her eyes. Sometimes a good movie like this is all we need to help us understand what we all go through when we reach the elder stage of life.

even with the subject matter-struggling with lack of independence-this movie has unexpected turns and gave a little window into how even as an elderly person, you still have life- loved when the son-brother only comes over to mom's house to do his laundry, even throws the socks he's wearing
into the load.

Too maudlin. Nothing uplifting or encouraging. Waste of talented actors and waste of my precious time. Would have preferred something about a senior with less self pity and more grit, like my mom who faces every painful day with courage.

A simple, but compelling and relevant work..  Characters are believable and the situation is one that most of us will face, in our own ways, if we live long enough.  It also shows us a glimpse of our future lives as care givers and maybe makes us a bit more sympathetic to the plight of those who are slipping into an age of helplessness or dementia.  I certainly appreciate anything that will help me prepare for the inevitable.  (If I live that long.)
Well...it's a powerful story that we might all have to face, so it's good to think about it. Yes, the music is pretty sappy, as was the ending.

I give it five stars because I am going through exactly what the daughter is going through. I was thinking to myself as I watched this is my life to a tee.  I am an only child I don't have siblings to share the load, it is all on me. My husband helps along with my oldest daughter, but my boys act just like the son did at first. They kept it real and to the point,  the early mornings, the stress of being a caretaker, wife, and mother. All the CHANGES and nobody really likes change especially with family routines. Yes this film is dated but the issue still exists.

I didn't care about any of thees characters.  Every scene was irritating and problematic.  Every character was on their last nerve and every one of them dragged their feet through the "burden" of taking care of business.  What I perceived was the two types of people who totally expect from family members even though their words belie this fact.  And the kind of people who are actually  independent takes care of matters long before becoming incapacitated.  ie: downsizing, getting rid of everything you are no longer using (every year, if you're not using it, get rid of it), instructions on what to do with your stuff after passing,  begin visiting places that you prefer to be taken to after you can't fend for yourself, written down documentation of accounts, passwords, IRA's, talking to families or resident's that have already transitioned to get ideas, names, addresses etc.  This all prepares oneself for the inevitable. No surprises, no burden on others and a much easier acceptance for the self.  Last, but not least, we must prepare spiritually.  We have to stay in relationship with God, we must pray for others, and pray for the Lord to prepare you for what you will go  through and for the courage and wisdom to let go of this temporary life on earth and prepare you for heaven, if that's your choice.  Begin to read your  bible daily, get a book on the "Promises of God". Start believing what God says (Isa 7:9) and stop clinging to life that has finished its lessons.  Bliss is on the other side.
VERY GOOD BUT EN-LIGHTING!  TO CLOSE TO HOME, DON'T WAIT FOR THE DAY BE IN THE PRESENT! DON'T SPEND TIME IN THE PAST OR THE FUTURE, WE ONLY CAN LOVE AND CHALLENGE OURSELVES IN THE MOMENT

One posted that "this film is food for thought for everyone who has an aging parent".  I think it is a good film for those who aging and in denial that this is going to happen one day.  The storyline was good but need a  something to make it livier. Nothing special about the filmography or the music as neither were bad or great. I liked the message the best.  "Grown old with Grace".
